Package com.rb.nonbiz.collections

Class RBStreams

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.collections.RBStreams
public class RBStreams
extends java.lang.Object
Various static utilities pertaining to Java 8 streams.

    A bit like Iterables.getOnlyElement, except that it allows for a default value if there's no element in the stream, and also allows for a clean precondition message if there are 2 or more elements.

  • Method Details

    • pasteIntoStream

      public static <T1,​ T2,​ R> java.util.stream.Stream<R> pasteIntoStream​(java.util.Iterator<T1> iterator1, java.util.Iterator<T2> iterator2, java.util.function.BiFunction<T1,​T2,​R> function)
      Creates a stream that results from applying some function of 2 args to the 'column paste' result of 2 iterators. Throws if the two iterators aren't of the same size.

    • pasteIntoStream

      public static <T1,​ T2,​ R> java.util.stream.Stream<R> pasteIntoStream​(java.util.Collection<T1> collection1, java.util.Collection<T2> collection2, java.util.function.BiFunction<T1,​T2,​R> function)
      Creates a stream that results from applying some function of 2 args to the i-th item on the left collection and i-th item on the right collection, for all i. Throws if the two iterators aren't of the same size.

    • pasteIntoStream

      public static <T1,​ T2,​ R> java.util.stream.Stream<R> pasteIntoStream​(java.util.List<T1> list1, java.util.List<T2> list2, java.util.function.BiFunction<T1,​T2,​R> function)
      Creates a stream that results from applying some function of 2 args to the i-th item on the left list and i-th item on the right list, for all i. Throws if the two iterators aren't of the same size.

    • pasteIntoStream

      public static <T1,​ T2,​ T3,​ R> java.util.stream.Stream<R> pasteIntoStream​(java.util.Iterator<T1> iterator1, java.util.Iterator<T2> iterator2, java.util.Iterator<T3> iterator3, TriFunction<T1,​T2,​T3,​R> function)
      Creates a stream that results from applying some function of 3 args to the i-th item on the 3 iterators, for all i. Throws if the three iterators aren't of the same size.

    • sumNonNegativeBigDecimals

      public static java.math.BigDecimal sumNonNegativeBigDecimals​(java.util.stream.Stream<java.math.BigDecimal> stream)
      Returns the sum of a bunch of BigDecimal objects. Throws if 1 or more is negative.

    • sumNonNegativeBigDecimals

      Returns the sum of a bunch of BigDecimal objects. Throws if 1 or more is negative.

    • sumNonNegativePreciseValuesToDouble

      public static <T extends PreciseValue<T>> double sumNonNegativePreciseValuesToDouble​(java.util.Collection<T> collection)

    • sumNonNegativePreciseValuesToDouble

      public static <T extends PreciseValue<T>> double sumNonNegativePreciseValuesToDouble​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream)

    • sumNonNegativeBigDecimalsToDouble

      public static double sumNonNegativeBigDecimalsToDouble​(java.util.stream.Stream<java.math.BigDecimal> stream)
      Adds a bunch of BigDecimal objects, and returns the result as a double. Throws if any are negative. If you don't care about the extra precision (e.g. because you have to use some math logic that only uses doubles and not BigDecimals), and just want a double, then use this. It's faster.

    • averageOfDoubleStream

      public static double averageOfDoubleStream​(java.util.stream.DoubleStream doubleStream)

    • averageOfDoubleIterator

      public static double averageOfDoubleIterator​(java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Double> iterator)

    • consecutivePairsStream

      public static <T,​ V> java.util.stream.Stream<V> consecutivePairsStream​(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable, java.util.function.BiFunction<T,​T,​V> consecutivePairTransformer)
      This does not have the performance benefits of a stream, as it precomputes each value (i.e. no lazy evaluation). However, a) it's nicer syntactically, as it doesn't expose the user to PairOfSameType<T> b) it's shorter to write

    • consecutiveNonOverlappingPairsStream

      public static <T,​ V> java.util.stream.Stream<V> consecutiveNonOverlappingPairsStream​(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable, java.util.function.BiFunction<T,​T,​V> pairTransformer)
      This does not have the performance benefits of a stream, as it precomputes each value (i.e. no lazy evaluation). However, a) it's nicer syntactically, as it doesn't expose the user to PairOfSameType<T> b) it's shorter to write

    • streamItemsAreUnique

      public static <T> boolean streamItemsAreUnique​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream)

    • concatenateFirstAndRest

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.stream.Stream<K> concatenateFirstAndRest​(K first, K... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least one item. But it can be used anywhere.

    • concatenateFirstAndRestDoubles

      @SafeVarargs public static java.util.stream.DoubleStream concatenateFirstAndRestDoubles​(double first, double... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least one item. But it can be used anywhere.

    • concatenateFirstSecondAndRest

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.stream.Stream<K> concatenateFirstSecondAndRest​(K first, K second, K... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least two items. But it can be used anywhere.

    • concatenateFirstSecondAndRestDoubles

      @SafeVarargs public static java.util.stream.DoubleStream concatenateFirstSecondAndRestDoubles​(double first, double second, double... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least two items. But it can be used anywhere.

    • concatenateFirstSecondThirdAndRest

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.stream.Stream<K> concatenateFirstSecondThirdAndRest​(K first, K second, K third, K... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least three items. But it can be used anywhere.

    • streamForEachUniqueUnorderedPairInList

      public static <K> java.util.stream.Stream<PairOfSameType<K>> streamForEachUniqueUnorderedPairInList​(java.util.List<K> items)
      If e.g. the keys are "a", "b", "c", this returns a stream of ("a", "b"), ("a", "c"), ("b", "c")

    • streamForEachUniquePair

      public static <K> java.util.stream.Stream<PairOfSameType<K>> streamForEachUniquePair​(RBSet<K> items)
      E.g. if you pass in keys A, B, C, D, this will operate on AB/BA, AC/CA, AD/DA, BC/CB, BD/DB, CD/DC. It expressly avoids looking at any pair (X, X), hence 'unique' (though that's not a great adjective here).

    • streamIsEmpty

      public static <T> boolean streamIsEmpty​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream)
      Tells you if a stream is empty, but note that it consumes the stream so you can't reuse it!

    • getOnlyElementOrDefault

      public static <T> T getOnlyElementOrDefault​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream, T defaultValue, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      A bit like Iterables.getOnlyElement, except that it allows for a default value if there's no element in the stream, and also allows for a clean precondition message if there are 2 or more elements.

    • getOptionalOnlyElement

      public static <T> java.util.Optional<T> getOptionalOnlyElement​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      If the stream has 1 item, returns it as non-empty optional. If it has 0 items, returns empty optional. Otherwise throws (with the supplied message) if there are 2 or more elements.

    • concatenateStreams

      @SafeVarargs public static <T> java.util.stream.Stream<T> concatenateStreams​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> first, java.util.stream.Stream<T> second, java.util.stream.Stream<T> third, java.util.stream.Stream<T>... rest)
      Stream.concat(Stream, Stream) only takes two arguments. You should still use it if you want to concatenate only 2 streams, but for 3 or more, the code will look unnecessarily nested with multiple calls to it. This solves that problem.
